awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Mechanical Behavior of Flexible Electronic Films
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) grant is to improve the understanding of the mechanical behavior of organic (polymeric) semiconductor films. Insight into the relationships between mechanical and electrical properties will provide guidelines to achieve mechanically robust flexible electronics for applications such as wearable electronics and low cost solar energy. Organic semiconductors are particularly promising for flexible electronics due to their relatively compliant nature associated with their molecular structure. Mechanical failure in use, primarily due to repeated flexing, has hindered the commercial adoption of organic films for flexible electronic applications. This award provides support to investigate the impact of molecular structure, film microstructure, and device design on performance variation and failure modes of devices under flexure. Research will also include the role of cyclic bending and environmental factors such as moisture on mechanical stability. This research crosses multiple disciplines including mechanics of materials, materials processing, and semiconductor device physics and will provide a stimulating training environment for students. The education plan includes the development of a certificate program in manufacturing and mechanics of emerging thin film electronics to train future leaders in this emerging field. 

The research objectives will be addressed through the following interrelated tasks: (i) determining the effect of molecular structure and molecular packing characteristics on the mechanical behavior of conjugated polymer films, (ii) establishing the impact of multi-component polymer blend morphology on electrical and mechanical response, (iii) characterizing interfacial features in heterogeneous films, such that delamination and cohesive failure modes can be mitigated, (iv) determining the features that drive performance variation and degradation under sub-critical mechanical loading under various loading protocols and environmental conditions, and (v) developing standardized mechanical test methods for flexible electronics. A focus will be on organic thin film transistors and organic photovoltaic devices that capture unique and fundamental operating characteristics so that the research products may be extrapolated across broad device platforms. Mechanical properties of interest include film stiffness, ductility, fracture strength, and cohesive and adhesive fracture energy that will be measured using four-point bending, double cantilever beam testing, and buckling metrology methods. The intellectual merit of the proposed research is found in the development of a fundamental framework relating polymer semiconductor structure to mechanical and optoelectronic characteristics enabling mechanically robust layered organic and organic-inorganic systems.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) grant was to improve the understanding of the mechanical behavior of organic (polymeric) semiconductor films. There have been a number of advancements associated with this broad objective. The research efforts can be broken down into two major themes: (1) understanding the determinants of mechanical behavior of organic solar cell active layers and approaches to improve mechanical stability; and (2) understand the fundamental drivers of ductility and stretchability of polymer semiconductors for flexible and stretchable device applications. Lastly, test methods have been developed that are needed to provide new insights into the mechanical behavior of thin (sub 200 nm-thick) neat conjugated polymer and polymer: small molecule blend films. To start, the thermomechanical behavior of conjugated polymer films were measured using dynamic mechanical analysis (DMA) showing complex behavior associated with their complex monomer structure. The thermal relaxations were attributed to various molecular features, determined through a comprehensive analysis of a library of conjugated polymers. We also showed that dropping the temperature of the films below the local thermal relaxation associated with the polymer side-chains can significantly reduce the film ductility. Furthermore, we showed that the simple crack onset strain measurement correlates with cohesive fracture energy of the films providing a means to better understand the fracture behavior of the materials. When moving towards stretchable applications, we investigated how the substrate adhesion and stiffness plays a large role in the crack onset strain, but also the ability of the film to be cyclically strained prior to large defect formation. This research provides guidelines to achieve stretchable devices that can undergo a large number of deformation cycles and remain functional. In regards to organic solar cells, we have considered details of both the mechanical and morphological stability of the active layers. We have shown that morphological stability requires stiff and glass materials that are inherently mechanically weak. We have analyzed the interactional of the small molecules and polymers (which are typically blended in solar cells) to establish how the morphological stability of the active layer can be improved while still maintaining some mechanical toughness. Furthermore, research has considered the use of all-polymer active layers as a means to improve the active layer mechanical stability. We have reported on the importance of polymer molecular weight and segregation behavior to achieve high efficiency and mechanically robust all-polymer solar cells. As part of these research outcomes, we have developed two test methods to gain insight into the mechanical behavior of the films. First we developed a tensile test with the conjugated polymer on a very thin (sub 4 micron) elastomer substrate that allows the film stress-strain response to be measured in both tension and compression. We have also developed a Kirigami-inspired cut patterned substrate to hold an organic semiconductor thin film to measure the thermomechanical behavior of device relavent films by DMA. The Kirigami-inspired testing is particularly powerful to measure behavior of blend films with a quenched morphology, which is typically the case in organic electronics.

The outreach activities as part of this grant has included participating in K-12 summer camps to introduce students to engineering design concepts. Topics and activities introduced to the students included energy conversion, optics, and materials science. The summer camps engagement included both week-long overnight camps and week-long day camps. The O’Connor research group also hosted undergraduate students, local high school teachers, and community college teachers as part of a Research Experience for Teachers program. In the RET program, the students and teachers worked on organic solar cell research related to this CAREER award. Finally, the grant supported four graduate students, all who have successfully received their PhD degrees.


Last Modified: 11/14/2022
Modified by: Brendan O'connor
